flooding.title: Flooding (Heavy Rain & Flash Floods)
quick: F.L.A.S.H.: Follow • Look • Avoid • Share • Help
Avoid floodwater; move to higher ground

sections.title: Stay informed (optional official alerts)
bullets: Enable heavy rain / water level alerts from official channels if you find them useful.
Road updates and flood advisories can help you plan a safer route.

sections.title: F.L.A.S.H. mnemonic
bullets: Follow official advisories and signs.
Look for waterlogged and flood-prone areas.
Avoid walking/driving through floodwater.
Share relevant safety updates.
Help others where it is safe to do so.

sections.title: Pedestrians
bullets: Avoid water deeper than your ankles; unseen drains are dangerous.
Use a stick/umbrella to check footing; keep to higher ground.
Stay away from canals and fast-moving water.

sections.title: Motorists
bullets: Do not enter water above kerb height or when road markings aren’t visible.
If passage is absolutely necessary and safe, go slowly and steadily—one vehicle at a time.
If the car stalls, do not restart; switch on hazards and move to higher ground.

sections.title: Homes & Buildings
bullets: Keep drains clear; deploy barriers early if available.
Move essential items to upper levels.
Switch off main power before evacuating; never touch switches if wet.

sections.title: After water recedes
bullets: Watch for hidden damage, open covers, and slippery debris.
Avoid contaminated water; re-enter only when it’s confirmed safe.

fire-safety.title: Fire Safety & What To Do in a Fire
quick: If trapped: safe room, block smoke

sections.title: If you discover a fire
bullets: Stay calm; shout for help and call emergency (995).
Alert others and evacuate quickly.
Close doors/windows of the fire room if safe; turn off gas if accessible.

sections.title: If trapped
bullets: Move to a room with a window facing the road; shut the door (don’t lock).
Block smoke at the bottom gap using wet towels/cloths.
Call for help and give your exact location; signal at the window.

sections.title: Using extinguishers (P.A.S.S.)
bullets: Pull the pin.
Aim at the base of the fire.
Squeeze the handle.
Sweep side-to-side.
Only attempt if the fire is small and you have a clear escape route.

sections.title: Prevention
bullets: Switch off appliances when not in use; don’t overload sockets.
Never leave cooking unattended; extinguish cigarette butts fully.
Keep exits and hose reels unobstructed; install smoke alarms.

sections.title: Evacuation
bullets: Use stairs—never lifts.
Head downwards; if stairwell is smoke-filled, shelter in a safe room.
Do not re-enter until authorities say it’s safe.

mosquito-dengue.title: Mosquito & Dengue: Symptoms and Prevention
quick: Know symptoms: fever, aches, rash, nausea
S-A-W: Spray • Apply repellent • Wear long sleeves

sections.title: Common symptoms
bullets: Sudden fever (2–7 days), headache (behind the eyes), muscle/joint pain.
Rash, nausea/vomiting, mild nose/gum bleeding.
Seek medical care if symptoms worsen.

sections.title: Protect yourself (S-A-W)
bullets: Spray insecticide in dark corners where mosquitoes rest.
Apply mosquito repellent regularly.
Wear long sleeves and pants, especially at dawn/dusk.

sections.title: Stop breeding (B-L-O-C-K)
bullets: Break up hardened soil; empty flowerpot plates.
Overturn pails; change water in vases.
Keep gutters/drains clear—tiny amounts of clean water can breed mosquitoes.

cpr-aed-adult.title: CPR + AED (Adult)
quick: DRS ABC: Danger • Response • Shout 995 • AED • Breathing

sections.title: Initial checks (DRS ABC)
bullets: Ensure safety; check responsiveness.
Shout for help and call emergency (speaker on).
Assess breathing—if not normal, start CPR.

sections.title: Start CPR
bullets: Hands in the center of the chest.
Rate 100–120/min, depth ~5–6 cm, allow full recoil.
Minimise pauses.

sections.title: Use an AED
bullets: Power on and follow voice prompts.
Bare/dry chest; place pads—upper right chest and lower left chest.
Announce “stay clear” during analysis/shock.

sections.title: Continue
bullets: Resume CPR immediately after shock or analysis.
Continue until normal breathing/response or handover to paramedics.

choking-adult.title: Choking (Adult)
quick: If severe: 5 back blows + 5 abdominal thrusts
If unresponsive: call 995 and start CPR

sections.title: Recognise
bullets: Unable to talk, weak/ineffective cough, bluish lips/skin, possible collapse.

sections.title: If mild obstruction
bullets: Encourage forceful coughing; monitor closely.

sections.title: If severe obstruction
bullets: Deliver up to 5 firm back blows between shoulder blades.
If not relieved, perform up to 5 abdominal thrusts.
Alternate 5 back blows and 5 thrusts until relieved or unresponsive.

sections.title: Special cases
bullets: Pregnant/obese: use chest thrusts (hands higher on the breastbone).
Self-choking: press your fist inward/upward against a firm surface.

sections.title: If unresponsive
bullets: Call emergency immediately; begin CPR.
Check mouth between cycles for visible objects (remove only if you can see it).

severe-bleeding.title: Severe Bleeding
quick: Add pads/bandage; don’t remove soaked dressings
Tourniquet if trained; treat for shock

sections.title: Control the bleeding
bullets: Wear gloves if available; expose the wound.
Apply firm direct pressure with a clean pad for at least 10 minutes.
Do not remove soaked dressings—add more on top and bandage firmly.

sections.title: If bleeding continues
bullets: Replace with a fresh bulky pad and reapply pressure.
If life-threatening limb bleeding and trained, apply a tourniquet 5–7 cm above the wound (not over joints). Note time.

sections.title: Embedded objects
bullets: Do NOT remove; pad around and bandage to stabilise without pressing on it.

sections.title: Internal bleeding / shock
bullets: Call emergency immediately.
Lay flat, elevate legs if appropriate, keep warm, monitor vital signs.

burns.title: Burns (Thermal)
quick: Do NOT pop blisters or apply creams

sections.title: Immediate care
bullets: Cool under cool running water for at least 20 minutes (no ice).
Remove jewelry/tight clothing before swelling; if stuck, cut around—don’t pull off.

sections.title: Cover & protect
bullets: Cover with sterile non-adhesive dressing, cling film, or clean cloth.
Avoid tissue/paper that sticks; avoid creams/grease.

sections.title: Seek urgent care if
bullets: Burn is large (> hand size), deep/white/charred.
Involves face, hands, feet, genitals, joints, airway.
Chemical/electrical burns, or child/elderly casualty.

sections.title: Recognise
bullets: Very high temperature, hot dry skin, confusion, collapse, unconsciousness.

sections.title: Immediate actions
bullets: Call emergency; move to a cool/shaded place.
Loosen/remove excess clothing.
If conscious, give small sips of cool water.

sections.title: Rapid cooling
bullets: Apply cold packs to neck, armpits, groin.
Wet skin + fan or immerse in cold water if appropriate.

sections.title: Red flags
bullets: Severe deformity, open wound, heavy trauma → call emergency.

sections.title: First aid (P.R.I.C.E.)
bullets: Protect & Rest the injured area.
Ice 15–20 minutes wrapped in cloth (intervals).
Compress with elastic bandage; Elevate above heart.

sections.title: Immobilisation
bullets: Do not straighten deformed limbs.
Immobilise the joint above and below if fracture is suspected.

sections.title: Seek medical help if
bullets: Severe pain, swelling, numbness, inability to move/bear weight.
No improvement after 2–3 days.
